content: The Model Context Protocol (MCP) has evolved from a local-only experiment into the de facto protocol for agentic systems within one year of its launch.
MCP has been adopted by major tech companies including OpenAI, Microsoft, Google, and Block, as well as hundreds of enterprises building internal agents at scale.
The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is joining the newly formed Agentic AI Foundation (AAIF) under the Linux Foundation.
Block's Goose coding agent is also joining the Agentic AI Foundation (AAIF) as a founding member.
Founding members of the Agentic AI Foundation (AAIF) include the biggest names in AI and cloud infrastructure.
Enterprises are deploying MCP servers rapidly, primarily for invisible, internal use at massive scale.

The 2025 vision for MCP is to serve as the communication layer for asynchronous, long-running agents that operate autonomously, discover and install their own tools, and significantly boost AI productivity.

MCP adoption is exploding internally at enterprises for connecting agents to various internal systems like Slack, Linear, proprietary data, and compliance-heavy workflows in sectors like financial services and healthcare.
Anthropic dogfoods MCP internally, using it for an internal gateway and custom servers for tasks like Slack summaries and employee surveys, indicating MCP was developed to scale internal dev tooling.
Tasks are a new primitive for long-running, asynchronous agent operations, designed as a 'container' to enable deep research and agent-to-agent handoffs, going beyond simple async tools.
MCP Apps utilize iframes to provide richer UI experiences beyond text interfaces, with use cases like seat selection and shopping UIs, developed in collaboration with OpenAI.

MCP requires a robust registry system, akin to 'npm for agents,' that includes features like signatures and compliance for HIPAA/financial regulations, supporting both official and curated sub-registries.
Code mode and MCP are complementary, with MCP providing connectivity and code mode focusing on optimization; Anthropic trains models with 'opinions' about tools, such as preferring `rg` over `grep`.
